cons: - growing pains from organizational shifts occurring during the exponential change from a $15M regional entity to an $80M+ national leader - communication and shared understanding will likely continue to develop at a rapid pace as more changes occur during national scaling continues

review_title: A Job that works with family empowerment
pros: A great opportunity to make a difference in all the families worked with and a strong focus on inclusive excellence
cons: Not applicable not applicable na

pros: Many members of the staff are pleasant and hard working.
cons: Toxic work environment is the primary con as well as the fact that there is no career path. It is good for one year max then you need to move on, Competitive rather than supportive interdepartmental relationships, and highly sporadic strategic decision making repeatedly taking place. Initially things appear to good to be true, they are.

review_title: Good Mission, but not well organized
job_title: Marketing in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great mission and some really amazing people.
cons: It takes a long time to go anything done, information literally goes in circles

pros: Great missions and amazing CEO. Benefits are great and they're working towards higher wages.
cons: Management changes frequently and can take you from having an amazing and supportive manager that helps you be one of the best employees, down to the bottom of the totem pole only a few weeks later when it changes. It's a lot of luck to stick with someone decent above you, and it can be long lastingly detrimental.

pros: Looks at salaries and tries to be competitive, and bonuses. People genuinely believe in the message/ mission statement. A small company, so you can feel like you’re making a difference. People are very nice
cons: Communication can be improved. Diversity and understanding of targeted regions could be improved. A lot of projects end up feeling like busy work. Poor health insurance coverage. Can be uncomfortable for people who aren’t religious

review_title: Great Mission but consistent reorganization/re-structuring and lay offs every few months
pros: Great organizational Mission with a truly caring founder. Great solid benefits. Depending on your territory, in sales you can do well. People are generally really nice. If you work remotely you don't have to deal with all the office politics.
cons: Lay offs and reorganizations across the board every few months. Even with good performance and high ratings on performance reviews. Sadly, really great competent people get laid off. The name of the game here is "we are re-structuring and are eliminating your position". This has happened to so many of my work friends among different departments I have lost track. Then that position is often seen on the careers page with different wording, possibly a slightly changed title- but essentially the same position - with in a few weeks. Unfortunately in 2022 Waterford.org still operates as an "old boys club" (which has been a BIG problem for years) picking, choosing and protecting their favorites. A few years ago there was a big push for DEI but many minority employees (at least my friends that are minorities) feel that it is for "show" and to appease those organizations/foundations funding and giving grants to certain Waterford programs at a very high dollar amount or their funding will be lost. Waterford is an 85%+ Mormon (LDS) organization and if you are not LDS you are perceived as an outsider in my experience. This is not said but 'felt" by many. Additionally, there has been high executive Directorship level staff turnover with in the last 3 years. The 2 top Marketing executives left for other opportunities, several Regional VPs of Sales left for other opportunities and VP/Director of Partnerships was just laid off along with other key Implementation/Success Managers/Directors who were laid off and or left for other opportunities. Its extremely stressful knowing that even if you do your job and do it well you may be let go at random no matter what department you are in. Many believe that layoffs are biased and those that are allowed to stay are based on favoritism, "popularity" and who you know in the organization - not based on performance. Additionally, they tend to lay off people that work remotely rather than those in the immediate area of the office. There are some wonderful people here but if you choose to come join the Waterford.org team, be certain to come with your eyes wide open and be aware that you could loose your job at any time on the whim of management, for no apparent reason and no matter what you brought to the table to make a bottom line difference in revenue or mission.

job_title: User Support Specialist in Sandy, UT
pros: Great goals as a org. Christmas break paid.
cons: Hard to move up in position

pros: Mission to bring learning content to kids. Creating equitable content to users. New content looks great.
cons: Disorganized project management and miscommunication. Lot's to do, but there is a lack of resources. The company wastes a lot of time on outdated ideas and systems.

review_title: The Best Company I've Ever Worked For
pros:
I don't even know if I can list all the pros.

Fantastic starting pay for a non-profit.

Excellent Benefits.

Insanely great HR Department and leadership in general.

Fantastic Company Culture overall. Real and true feelings like the company actually cares for me and cares about making me feel good while working at the company.
cons:
Been told by others they sometimes feel like it's hard to move up to other positions due to need. I believe they're getting better at this from what I've seen since I started. 

Non Profit company does come with some typical drawbacks but much less than others I am familiar with.

pros: Remote work, Good company culture, Emphasis on diversity and inclusion. Good benefits.
cons: N/A, I love it here.

pros: Inclusive, caring, treats you like a human
cons: Small company with a tight budget. People get laid off fairly often.

review_title: So much potential with the right leadership
job_title: Sr. Marketing Manager in Taylorsville, UT

cons: Transitional leadership roles. I had 7 people to report to in one year.

pros: I love the people I work with and find the work to be fulfilling. The mission of the organization is amazing.
cons: Need to be more opportunities for advancement. Promoting from within should be more common considering how wonderful all the employees are.

job_title: Managing Director in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
I've worked for Waterford for several years and when I first got here it was very chaotic and seemed unorganized. The only thing that kept me going was that everyone in the company was striving toward the same goal, helping the poorest of children learn to read which will change their lives for the better and it was a mission that I wanted to be a part of. 

Over the years, the company has gone through a huge transformation that has been awesome. We now have clear visions of the projects we need to complete, clear and achievable goals, and good communication between departments and company-wide. It is very rewarding to work here because we can see how we are impacting the lives of the children we serve for the better. I have worked at many other companies where the profit margin was the most important goal and I wouldn't go back to any one of those companies for all the money in the world.

The benefits offered are very competitive, the management has been awesome to work for, and all of our executives have an open door policy and encourage people to speak up if they have an idea, a compliment, or a complaint.
cons: None that I can think of

pros:
Great benefits
Great people
Great pay
cons:
No consistency
Lack of communication

pros: Waterford.org is committed to and acts based on the organization's Mission. Communication is transparent and leadership is trusted. Workplace culture is positive, people are nice, and there is strong CEO leadership. Key Performance Indicators are used effectively to strive toward the Mission. Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion are advocated for and acted upon with trackable goals. The benefits are excellent. Employees are treated as whole people, opposed to numbers. The programs, Upstart (4-year-old children) and Waterford Reading Academy (PreKindergarten to Grade 2 school program) are quality offerings that are effective in striving toward the organization's Mission Pillars: Equity, Family Empowerment, and Universal Literacy. The offerings Waterford.org has, such as Family Acadamy, Family Education Liaisons, and Education Coaches are distinctive competencies no one can compete with.
cons: There are no Cons that would be a barrier to enjoying employment at Waterford.org.

job_title: Director in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Waterford.org is an amazing organization. The non-profit sector, Waterford Upstart, is truly changing lives! Waterford Upstart is an adaptive software that is free for the families and is used in the home. When used consistently, this product can change lives! We have thousands of testimonials to back that up! Look at our data and look at our reviews. The product works and children that use it consistently are better prepared for a successful academic career. The Executive team is really striving to make Waterford.org a destination work place. Also, as an organization, we are very focused on raising the bar when it comes to our DEI commitment. If you truly believe in early childhood education and want to help change the trajectory of a little life, check us out!
cons: Because we are growing so fast, sometimes we struggle to keep up with cutting edge tools and data platforms to support our families. However, our Executive team is going to great lengths to provide us with the tools we need to support our families. We are also hiring more rock star employees to help with bandwidth!

pros: Waterford.org is an awesome organization to work for with an incredible mission. They responded correctly to the events of 2020 with safety, compassion and a growth mindset. Waterford.org also provided an academic response to COVID-19 for all families they serve. If you’re passionate about helping children grow a lifelong love for learning at home, this is the organization for you. Great benefits, awesome pay, as well as an amazing and diverse management team that listens! Tons of opportunity for growth.

pros: Waterford.org is an organization with many folks who care deeply about education for themselves and others. Most folks are devoted to learning more, growing, and helping make the work stronger. The overall majority is dedicated to progress and improvement.
cons: Waterford.org has a long tradition of white, male leadership, even as the mission has expanded over many decades to serving more BIPOC. While strides are being made to find additional staff who look and sound more like those served, leadership is somewhat inoculated from that overall trend, with power continuing to rest mostly in the hands of white men.

pros:
Waterford's mission to ensure a great start for every child is one that is felt across the organization. Its people are passionate about what they do and genuinely care about making a difference in the world. 

It's a small organization that has gone through quite a bit of transition the past few years and has many of the stresses that one would equate with a non profit in the edtech space. Despite that, it's a great place to be able to have an impact every day and to be able to make changes that help direct the company on the right path. 

Leadership is friendly and genuinely cares about the people working for them and the executives are very accessible to the broader organization. 

Benefit package is fair and you cannot beat the location with the mountains right outside the window.
cons:
Being a non profit means that funding is always tight and so many of the perks that are common place in tech companies today are non existent. It's a humble office with the focus on the work instead of around creating high quality work spaces. 

There is a lack of alignment in terms of priorities and direction and a hesitation around decision making at the executive level which makes it difficult to know what's most important at times.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
You get to work with passionate people who care about the company's goals. The company is fairly small which gives you an opportunity to really influence decisions and make an impact, if that's what you want. There has been a lot of opportunities for me to cross-train and get a fuller picture of all facets of early learning software development.

The Sandy office is on the school campus (which is beautiful), and employees get a discount on the cafeteria during the school year, which is great for cheap lunches. 

I believe that Waterford truly cares about its employees. The founder likes to walk around and talk to everyone and all of the VPs are approachable. I feel like people know me and care about what I think.
cons: There's a lack of decisiveness with the top leaders, which leads to the loudest voice in the room getting what they want rather than going with an informed decision. The company sometimes feels like it's going in five directions at once. It takes a lot of effort to get everyone on the same page, and it feels like that effort only comes from the bottom rather than the top. Sometimes it feels like true communication only happens when something is overheard by accident.

job_title: Personal Care Representative in Taylorsville, UT
pros:
The Upstart program for preschoolers is amazing and works.  Period. 

I enjoy the work atmosphere with my fellow personal care reps, the team leads, and upper management.  I always feel like the call center manager has an open door, and is willing to listen and work with you (especially when it comes to scheduling issues).  I've never felt uncomfortable in approaching any team lead or member of management with issues that I've had.  The team leads and management's upbeat personalities and attitudes make coming to work enjoyable and fun.  

There is room for growth with the company and they truly value professional development. 

The benefits are great!  You can sign up to work on holiday's for extra vacation time, which is a valuable perk. They slow down in the summer so it is a perfect opportunity to take a summer trip with all the vacation time that you rack up.
cons: It would be nice if all the Personal Care Representatives could all have new computers and monitors but it is non profit so we take what we can get.

pros:
I truly loved my time and experience at the Waterford Institute.  It almost felt unreal, but everyone's true intentions are revolved around the children and learning.  It was incredible to see and be a part of that.  They are an extremely family oriented company - and the only one I can honestly say puts 'the family first'.  They worked with me and my schedule in ways that I cannot see anyone else providing, and I am so thankful for that.  My time at Waterford will always be cherished and remembered, and one day when the timing is better, I may find my way back.  
To date - they have the best benefits I've encountered, all starting day 1.  Incredible retirement benefits.
cons: I didnt experience anything that I would consider a con.

review_title: One of a long line of terminated employees
pros: The paid time off is a pretty good benefit - most of the federal holidays, and an extended Christmas holiday. If you are inspired by education and software, this might be a good fit.
cons: It was a challenge to work for the pay offered here. I believe I was better compensated than my co-workers. While the organization is relatively flat, management is very top heavy. As there are some exceptional individuals who work there, there are those in upper management who great vision and drive, but lack in human resource management skills.

pros: The vision of the company and founders is admirable! The idea behind Upstart and helping every child start on equal footing is the reason I came to work for this company.
cons: The company has gone from valuing employees to seeing them as strictly profit and gain at the employee's expense.  What used to be a family friendly and caring company has been reduced to meeting numbers.  They can't keep employees because management treats us as a number and has made it clear they don't care.  The turn over rate is at its highest! They can't keep employees to meet the criteria of supporting the 15,000 families they hope to gain.

pros: Company Mission was to provide education and essential equipment to children in low income families. Ability to take time off.
cons: Too many restructures and layoffs. People that write the content are out of touch with technology and the way kids learn and dumbed things down way too much. They are behind the times as far as what makes kids interested in educational learning. Too many underqualified people in higher up positions that don't know how the product works.  Poor communication between departments always felt like things were done over and over. Opinions on how to streamline processes and improve things were often dismissed. Difficult to get a pay raises.  Pay not equal.

review_title: Great place to work on projects that matter.
pros: The Waterford Institute is a great place to work.  I was never expected to work outside of normal work hours.  The projects were exciting and designed to help children read.  This company really is set out to make a difference and it was great to be a part of that.
cons: As a research company the art department has had varying degrees of oversight.  There is little direction or ability to grow outside of working on things yourself.  Due to the lack of demand members of the team were able to get away with doing nothing for large amounts of time.  Frustrating as someone who wanted to grow.

pros:
My manager has been extremely nurturing and helped my development grow very much over the years.  I've been guided toward excellence and constant improvement and accountability WITHOUT being micro-managed, which is rare!  My manager watches closely for hidden and not-so-hidden talents, abilities and interests in the employees and once someone demonstrates responsibility and effort, my manager provides more opportunities for that employee to grow further.  

The company in general works really hard to take care of the employees.  The benefits package is outstanding!
cons: The workload can be heavy but I'd certainly rather be busy than bored!  And I know the work I'm doing makes a significant and lasting difference for the better in people's lives, which is really important to me.

review_title: Compensation is competitive and I love the people I work with
pros:
Working at Waterford has been great! I first worked as an intern for 2 years and then was promoted to a marketing position the following year. Since working here, I have had 4 direct bosses: Claudia, Ann, Taylor, and Diane. They have all been great to work for and I have really respected them. 
I wasn't planning on staying here after my internship, but I really believed in the company and I have felt like they have been completely honest and fair with me.
cons: The break room needs a sink. :)

pros: I have worked for Waterford for 10 years. I have enjoyed working with many hundreds of individuals over that time. Every person that contributes to the passion and mission of Waterford has been a joy to work with. I have been fortunate to be a part of it for so long.
cons: Over the years there have been many changes in focus and direction for the company. Operating a not-for-profit is not easy - especially during a recessed economy. Being reliant upon the whims and budgets of various educational organizations that are our consumers is a constant challenge.

pros:
-Paid 
-Most interns come from BYU, BYU-I, UofU, or Utah State and everyone is super friendly
-Opportunity for plenty of hours
-Opportunity to travel all over Utah
-Sufficient training and clear objectives
cons:
-Sometimes you'll have to work weird hours especially if you are on a traveling team
-The work gets very monotonous by the end of the summer
-Not my best paid internship, but definitely fair pay
-Does not offer a path to full-time employment after graduation
-Sometimes upper management come off as intimidating/mean

review_title: All-around worth considering as a potential employer.
pros: This company cares about work/life balance and in general has managers that care about their employees. They offer competitive compensation for a non-profit, and build a product you can be proud of. They are very supportive of professional development.
cons: The company is heavy on senior management, especially, considering its size. Along those lines the number of people in senior management seems to create a situation where there are too many cooks in the kitchen and affects the company's ability to set a clear direction.

review_title: Management is very flexible with schedules, compassionate with employees.
job_title: Certified Medication Aid in Omaha, NE
pros: I like working here for the location, flexibility of schedule, and growth potential within the company.  Opportunities for growth, leadership positions, and opportunities to build relationships with family members and the community.
cons: Benefit package is very limited. Need to be able to access PTO before the one year probation period is over, have a waiting period of 90 days would be beneficial.

pros: Great mission in an organization that walks the walk.  Alignment to mission is always brought up in both large and small decisions.  Sense of purpose is a great benefit as we're helping kids prepare for school and succeed in school.   A lot of room to grow .
cons: As a nonprofit - much is asked of each person.  Sandy office could use an update.

pros: The Institute has a fabulous mission to use technology to help educate disadvantaged children.
cons: The institute is struggling with a vision of where to go as its sales have dropped dramatically and cash flow has become a major concern.  Major layoffs have occurred and will continue to occur for the foreseeable future.  Beware if you accept a position here it is likely a very unstable situation and new hires are especially at risk.

review_title: Regretful - it could have been so much better
job_title: Programmer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Fun people and when you join you feel like you will be making a difference.
cons: There is simply no direction from the management.  There are so many VP members but only a handful of "worker bees".  I often felt like management was trying to justify why they were going on so many trips when the company was trying to cut back to save money.  The turnover within the company is also not helpful - once you are there it is difficult to feel "secure".  You never knew when your head would be the next on the chopping block.

review_title: UPSTART- Great for the kids, horrible for the employees.
pros: Upstart is a great program for the children who participate in the year long program. The kids learn a ton in the short amount of time. The idea that children have access to an innovated software that helps them learn the fundamentals before entering kindergarten is a fantastic tool and resource for families.
cons: The idea of UPSTARTS innovation is fantastic; however, the employees are treated like children. The company recently made some management changes, and with those management changes came a shift in the company's idea of priorities.  The company has lost sight of their original mission- which was helping children- and now it is more about how many children they can get to participate in the program. They stopped caring about the people who work there and because of that, in July alone, they lost over 30 employees. The turnover rate has been escalating from there. With the lose of great people, they have been spiraling downward ever since. Part of the reason people have chosen to leave is because they didn't feel valued, they were being micromanaged, and even their break time (even slightly over the allotted 30 minutes) were being taken out of their pay. Employee's weren't being listened too, and with multiple surveys that were done on the floor, management still maintained that they were not doing anything wrong.  After a survey was completed the director took all of the voices of the employees personal, and tried to reprimand the person who reported the results. Management would offer promotions, and then when the position would finally open, they would give it to someone less qualified.  The overall environment at the Taylorsville office, for UPSTART, has been downsized to fit a model similar to any other call centers, and  what once was a very loving place to support families and children's learning has become practically a dictatorships. It's where managers treat you like you are not adult enough to do your work, and support other families.

review_title: Massive Layoffs Regularly!!! Avoid at all cost.
pros:
Let me be clear... I was not laid off. I was one of the few that managed to avoid this, but it was because of the constant layoffs that I quickly looked for other work. 

Pros: Free juice and fruit. Nice co-workers.
cons: Yearly layoffs. Management is so incompetent that it ends up in massive layoffs every year. Incredibly bad direction. Poor decision making. Owner hired incompetent son to be CEO (and we never saw him). More VP's than employees.

review_title: Great products but not a destination workplace
pros:
Great products created here
A good place to learn and grow
cons:
Administration only wants to cut spendings by doing absurd things like buying the lowest quality products, postponing agreed salary increases, canceling business trips in the last moment because the flight is cheaper later etc
No respect for regular employees, lot of talks behind close doors, low transparency

review_title: Highly creative products backed by great research, watch out for layoffs
pros: Overall Waterford has some great educational products and very talented staff. The management has been in the industry for some time and the research behind the products appears solid.
cons: The top down communication could be better. The company has had its ups and downs financially and has had periodic layoffs, one of which affected me.

job_title: Personal Care Representative in Taylorsville, UT
pros: Awesome PTO, Benefits, great partners to the company, great future ahead with amazing teams.
cons: Be aware of the change of UPSTART is growing rapidly so be prepared to work in a company that is consistently growing for the better.

review_title: Rewarding small non-profit with a global footprint

cons: Sometimes financing can be shaky and senior leadership strategies can create periods of fluctuating head-count.

job_title: Field Engineer in West Valley City, UT
pros: Small company, good culture, great benefits, and when the work is there it is good
cons: Departments don't necessarily get along from time to time, organizational structure is confusing and the product itself does have issues

review_title: The most dysfunctional management group I have had the entertainment pleasure to work.
pros: The temporary illusion of helping children along with proximity to some great skiing. Great vibrant market connecting technology and education.
cons: No appreciation for organizational culture or respect for the skills of the employees. No communication skills among leadership team. Uncanny ability to rationalize all kinds of unprofessional and sketchy behavior.

job_title: User Support in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The cereal and juice each morning is a great perk and working with great employees.  The benefits are also what lure an individual to work there.
cons: There are so many layoffs at the company and very little vision.  It often seemed as though we would start work on something only to be told that our priorities were changing.  This happened frequently.

cons: Lack of standardization across groups makes communication difficult at times
